children.subject: Agree, I just checked Shewchuk semesters, 189 hw assignment even more Math than math class.

One potential benefit I can think of is that Data 100 gives you a lot of practical skills, whereas 126/127/189 have a tendency to be more theoretical and math-heavy. For example Data 100 gives you the opportunity to get familiar working with a lot of Python libraries like numpy, pandas, matplotlib, sklearn, Pytorch. These tools could come in handy with any machine learning project. This is particularly the case if you end up taking CS 189 in the fall. During non-Shewchuk semesters, 189 homework assignments have a historical tendency to place more emphasis on math and proofs and less emphasis on practicing real-life ML coding.

I think that if you wanna go into ML/DS, Data100 is a great class to take early on. It's one of those classes that have fewer pre-requisites, and is kind of a "crash course to Data Science". So, many people take it in their sophomore year to help with their sophomore/junior year internships. This way, you can get started with DS projects early on before you even take CS189.

history.content: <md>If I'm planning a career in machine learning and I've decided to take EECS 126, EECS 127, and CS 189 (in different semesters during my undergrad), what benefits exist to taking Data 100 (with Stat 20 or Data 8 before since I haven't done those yet)? I want to know whether I should try to integrate this set of courses into my schedule. Thanks!</md>
history.subject: Benefits of DS 100 for ML career
